initialResearchSummary: Alright, let’s kick back and take a stab at what Moody Tunes might be about based on that URL alone. The name itself gives off some pretty cool vibes—sounds like a spot that’s all about music, right? I mean, “tunes” is a classic word for songs, and “moody” suggests there’s some emotional or atmospheric depths to dig into. I can imagine Moody Tunes being a platform where music lovers can discover tracks that really match their mood. You know, like when you’re feeling chill and just want some lo-fi beats, or maybe you’re in the mood to rock out? It could be a hub for playlists tailored to different vibes, helping folks find the perfect sound for whatever they’re up to—studying, chilling, partying, or just taking a long drive. And hey, maybe it’s got some cool features like mood-based algorithms or a user-generated playlist section. Picture this: you log in after a long day, select “stressed” from a little mood menu, and boom—out pops a playlist designed to soothe your soul. That sounds pretty dope, right? Another angle could be that they’re curating a bunch of indie artists and tracks, giving some love to the underground scene. If that’s the case, you might find gems that aren’t blaring on the radio but deserve to be heard. Plus, maybe they spotlight different artists or genres each month, keeping the content fresh and introducing listeners to new sounds. I can also see them having a community vibe—maybe a forum for music lovers to chat about their favorite tracks or share personal playlists. It’d be cool to see folks sharing their own “mood mixes” and getting feedback from others. You could swap recommendations and discover hidden treasures together. And let’s not forget about aesthetics. If it’s called Moody Tunes, you can bet the site might have some atmospheric visuals—think moody colors, maybe some abstract art or imagery that makes you feel a certain way just by looking at it. A clean, user-friendly design would be essential too. Who wants to sift through clutter when you’re just trying to find a song that resonates with your feelings? In a nutshell, I’d say Moody Tunes is probably this chill, music-centric space where you can explore tunes that align with your emotional state. Whether it’s a rainy day, a lively get-together, or a reflective evening, this site seems like it’s got your back with the right soundtrack to match. So grab a drink, kick back, and maybe dive into Moody Tunes to see what musical moods it has lined up for you. Who knows? You might just find your next favorite jam nestled in there, waiting to vibe with your soul. Cheers!

researchResults.content: Published Time: 2017-02-07T22:30:11.000Z Rainy-Day Playlist | PS Smart Living Skip to main content Popsugar Subscribe Go to Navigation Smart Living Music The Perfect Playlist For a Rainy Day By Macy Cate Williams Updated on Feb 11, 2017 at 1:30 PM StockSnap | Gabriele Diwald StockSnap | Gabriele Diwald The rain is pouring, the sky is gloomy, and all you want to do is stay inside — we know that feeling. There's nothing better than cozying up with a blanket and staying indoors. We curated a playlist that perfectly captures that rainy-day mood. Whether you're in the office or stuck at home, these songs are exactly what you need. Press play. "Work Song," Hozier "Poison & Wine," The Civil Wars "Islands," The xx "Banana Pancakes," Jack Johnson "No One's Gonna Love You," Band of Horses "Set the Fire to the Third Bar," Snow Patrol, Martha Wainwright "Latch (Acoustic)," Sam Smith "Sound & Color," Alabama Shakes "Holocene," Bon Iver "In the Waiting Line," Zero 7 "Each Coming Night," Iron & Wine "White Winter Hymnal," Fleet Foxes "New Slang," The Shins "Mess Is Mine," Vance Joy "Love on the Weekend," John Mayer "Ordinary People," John Legend "Over My Dead Body," Drake "No Diggity," Chet Faker "Hallelujah," Jeff Buckley "Slow It Down," The Lumineers "Breathe Me," Sia "First Day of My Life," Bright Eyes "Barcelona," George Ezra "The Cave," Mumford & Sons "I Will Follow You Into the Dark," Death Cab For Cutie "Home," Edward Sharpe & The Magnetic Zeros "Need the Sun to Break," James Bay "Keep Your Head Up," Ben Howard "Northern Wind," City and Colour "Don't Panic," Coldplay Don't forget — you'll need to download the free Spotify software or app to listen to our playlists! Subscribe to our Spotify account to see what other playlists we have for you. researchResults.content: Published Time: 2022-03-30T17:34:25Z 27 Top Rainy Day Songs: Best Wet Weather Playlist × Skip to main content Open menu Search Click to Expand Search Input Billboard Billboard Search Click to Expand Search Input LOGIN Login Account Manage Account Log Out Account Search Click to Expand Search Input Charts Music Video Shop Awards Business Billboard Charts Music Video Shop Awards Business LOGIN Login Click to Expand Search Input Account Manage Account Log Out Account Billboard Hot 100 Year-End Charts 21st Century Charts Honda Stage Billboard Music Awards Family Global News Español Open menu Search Click to Expand Search Input Billboard Billboard Search Click to Expand Search Input LOGIN Login Account Manage Account Log Out Account Search Click to Expand Search Input Charts Music Video Shop Awards Business 03/30/2022 27 Top Rainy Day Songs Put on your favorite sweatpants and queue up these tracks from current hitmakers, up-and-comers and musical legends for your next rainy day. By Danielle Pascual Danielle Pascual More Stories by Danielle How Myles Smith Turned a Working Demo Into a Hot 100 Hit: ‘There’s So Much Beauty in Imperfection’ Did ‘1989 (Taylor’s Version)’ Cap Off the Most Dominant Month of Taylor Swift’s Career? How Does Olivia Rodrigo’s ‘Guts’ Debut Compare to Our Post-‘Sour’ Expectations? View All 03/30/2022 Share on Facebook Share on X Share to Flipboard Share on Pinterest + additional share options added Share on Tumblr Share on Reddit Share on LinkedIn Share on Whats App Send an Email Print this article Post a Comment Camilo Fuentes Beals/EyeEm/GI Sweatpants, a good book, your favorite warm drink and some music to mellow out to: These are the necessities for any given rainy day. While it may seem like a downer that the sun is M.I.A., gray clouds have taken over the sky and outdoor activities have become a thing of the past, take it as an opportunity to relax and reflect as the raindrops hit the pavement. Lucky for you, Billboard has handpicked 27 songs by current hitmakers, up-and-comers, and musical legends alike to add to your rainy-day playlist. From chill wave electronic tracks like Medasin’s remix of Portugal. The Man’s “Feel It Still,” to guitar driven numbers like Led Zeppelin’s “The Rain Song,” to ambient tunes like SZA’s “Good Days,” there is something on this list for every kind of music fan. Whether the dreary day has you thinking about your future or reminiscing on your past, queue up these calming tracks to further that cozy feeling. Led Zeppelin, “The Rain Song” Led Zeppelin photographed in 1973. Photo : Hulton Archive/GI Though it’s not their longest song at nearly 8 minutes, “The Rain Song” is one of Led Zeppelin’s only ballads — and features strong vocals from lead singer Robert Plant. Listen here. Portugal. The Man, “Feel It Still” (Medasin Remix) In his remix, Medasin adds an unexpected layer of chill to Portugal. The Man’s otherwise hype track, “Feel It Still.” Listen here. Etta James, “A Sunday Kind of Love” Etta James’ raw vocals shine alongside a string ensemble in “A Sunday Kind of Love” off her 1964 album At Last. Listen here. Jack Johnson, “Banana Pancakes” Rain doesn’t have the best reputation — but with “Banana Pancakes,” Jack Johnson reminds us that some of the most memorable days are spent indoors with the person you love. Listen here. Bad Bunny, “TRELLAS” Bad Bunny Photo : STILLZ Bad Bunny’s vocals soar alongside an acoustic guitar and unique background sounds in his laid-back ballad, “TRELLAS.” Listen here. SZA, “Good Days” When negativity floods your mind, SZA’s dreamy track “Good Days” assures you that brighter times are ahead. Listen here. Rex Orange County, “Pluto Projector” Beautiful harmonies and a string ensemble come together to create Rex Orange County’s cosmic love song “Pluto Projector.” Listen here. Louis The Child feat. Ashe, “World On Fire” Ashe contributes delicate vocals to Louis The Child’s “World On Fire,” his 2017 track shedding light on global warming. Listen here. Patrick Watson, “Je te laisserai des mots” Patrick Watson’s piano-driven track “Je te laisserai des mots” is equally heartwarming as it is heartbreaking and has become a favorite among TikTok users. Listen here. Billie Eilish, “Halley’s Comet” Billie Eilish Photo : Kelia Anne MacCluskey* Billie Eilish puts her famous breathy vocals and emotions at the forefront in her Happier Than Ever love song, “Halley’s Comet.” Listen here. Elena Rose, “Picachu” Whether a lover or a friend, Elena Rose’s soothing single “Picachu” is a song to dedicate to anyone you care about. Listen here. Ray Charles, “Come Rain or Come Shine” Ray Charles puts his own bluesy spin on “Come Rain or Come Shine,” made famous by Frank Sinatra, for his 1959 album The Genius of Ray Charles. Listen here. Phoebe Bridgers & Jackson Browne, “Kyoto” Phoebe Bridgers taps iconic singer-songwriter Jackson Browne for an intimate version of her Punisher single “Kyoto.” Listen here. WILLIS, “I Think I Like When It Rains” Produced with an old-school sound, WILLIS’ “I Think I Like When It Rains” makes you reminisce on the best days with the best people. Listen here. Daniel Caesar, “Japanese Denim” Daniel Caesar Photo : Ciesay* In “Japanese Denim,” Daniel Caesar soulfully sings about a love that will last a lifetime — like a great pair of jeans. Listen here. Arctic Monkeys, “Only Ones Who Know” A simple electric guitar riff accompanies Arctic Monkeys frontman Alex Turner’s somber vocals in “Only Ones Who Know.” Listen here. Lauri Garcia, “Miel” Mainly comprised of a simple ukulele strum pattern, Lauri Garcia’s “Miel” is a rainy day love song for the ages. Listen here. Sufjan Stevens, “Mystery of Love” Nominated for best original song at the 2018 Oscars, Sufjan Stevens’ “Mystery of Love” from Call Me By Your Name is a poetic number about first loves and heartbreak. Listen here. Billy Joel, “Vienna” Billy Joel embraces getting older in his piano-driven classic “Vienna.” Listen here. Lana Del Rey, “Mariners Apartment Complex” Lana Del Rey "Mariners Apartment Complex" Photo : Courtesy Photo Lana Del Rey’s rich vocals drive “Mariners Apartment Complex,” her dreamy lead Norman F—king Rockwell single about helping someone who’s lost. Listen here. Leon Bridges, “River” In “River,” Leon Bridges soulfully sings an ode to salvation alongside gentle guitar strums and a slow tambourine clap. Listen here. ford., “Bedford Falls” ford. marries soft synth beats and an addictive piano melody in his instrumental lo-fi track “Bedford Falls.” Listen here. Emmit Fenn, “Lost in Space” Emmit Fenn transports listeners to another world with his dreamy chillwave track “Lost in Space.” Listen here. eAeon feat. RM, “Don’t” With a feature from BTS’ RM, eAeon sings about heartbreak and begging someone to stay in “Don’t.” Listen here. Shakira, “Moscas en la Casa” Before proclaiming her “hips don’t lie,” Shakira sings a pop ballad about love and longing in “Moscas en la Casa.” Listen here. Frank Ocean, “Moon River” Frank Ocean Photo : Collier Schorr Frank Ocean isn’t the first to cover “Moon River” — but he gives the Breakfast at Tiffany’s track new life with his distinctive hazy vocals and R&B sound. Listen here. Maroon 5, “Sunday Morning” “Sunday Morning” is a Maroon 5 classic that will have you eager for a rainy day inside with the person you love. Listen here. Gallery Virtual Top Sectionals Gallery Virtual Recliner Gallery Blog 6 Playlists for Rainy Days April 7, 2021 by Bill Welles From Our Expertselectronicsplaylistrainy day playliststreaming When rain is crashing against your window and wind is whipping with reckless abandon, sometimes all you want to do is stay indoors—and we can certainly relate. When you’re hit with a case of April showers, this is the perfect time to curl up with a warm blanket, your coziest pair of sweatpants, and unwind with a soothing playlist. If you’ve got spring fever, the last thing you want to see are gloomy skies and dark clouds occupying the warm, invigorating rays of the sun. However, while the warm weather is temporarily M.I.A., this allows you to discover some new music while you relax and watch the rainfall. Whether you’re glued to the couch or spending the day in bed, we’ve curated a few playlists from Spotify that are sure to lift your spirit and capture the pure essence of a rainy day. Grab your headphones and get ready to press “play.” 1. Rainy Day Classics If you’re a fan of 60s, 70s, and 80s hits, then you couldn’t ask for a better playlist. With 52 songs in total and over three hours of pure nostalgia, this selection of tunes will help get you through the rainy day and automatically send you back in time. This playlist is not to be confused with “dad rock” (even though your dad probably had most of these songs on cassette). This is a playlist for all ages to enjoy. It’s full of timeless, feel-good music that can help pass the time and revitalize your otherwise lethargic rainy afternoon. Featuring artists such as Creedence Clearwater Revival, The Beatles, Tom Petty, Fleetwood Mac, and more, this rainy day playlist may just turn into your everyday playlist. 2. Rainy Day Kids If you’re stuck indoors during a storm, odds are your kids are stuck at home with you. As much as kids would prefer to be outside playing with their friends, a rainy day creates an opportunity to play some fun and educational songs to keep them energized throughout the day. Songs like “Mr. Sun,” “Rain, Rain Go Away,” and “Singing in the Rain” are some all-time favorites that your kids are sure to recognize and sing along to. And any playlist that features songs by Raffi is a no-brainer if you’re searching for children's music. 3. Songs About Rain Sometimes, the best way to get through a stormy day is to embrace and immerse yourself in the weather. If it’s still pouring and the old man is still snoring, how about dedicating your playlist to songs written about rain? It makes sense to us! Songs like “Make It Rain” by Ed Sheeran, “Set Fire to the Rain” by Adele, “No Rain” by Blind Melon, and “One Rainy Wish” by Jimi Hendrix are just a few of the songs featured as part of this 52-track playlist. Whether or not you’re a fan of rainy weather, music is always the best way to add a little warmth to a chilly day. 4. Rainy Day Jazz There’s just something about a rainy day that makes you feel like sitting at a coffee shop with a latte in hand enjoying some jazz music in the background. Whether you’re a fan of smooth jazz, freeform, or bebop, this rainy day jazz playlist mimics that feeling—all you need is a fresh cup of joe. You can close your eyes and listen to the trumpets, trombones, and saxophones hitting each note with incredible elegance and vigor—envisioning a time where Miles Davis, Louis Armstrong, John Coltrane, and Duke Ellington were on top of the charts. Featuring 92 songs and over six hours of music, this playlist is sure to serve as your introductory lesson to one of the earliest and most profound genres of music. 5. Rainy Day Country If you’re not a fan of nursery rhymes, jazz, or rock music, there are plenty of other music genres out there for you to explore. Maybe you prefer country music? Well, in that case, throw on your 10-gallon hat and pair of overalls because we’ve got the ultimate rainy day country playlist, partner. With 463 songs and 24 hours of music, this playlist is long enough to outlast any storm. The artists include Carrie Underwood, Luke Bryan, Blake Shelton, Kacey Musgraves, Sam Hunt, and more. It might be raining, but no one can stop you from throwing your own Stagecoach Festival from home. 6. Rainy Days Music for Mellowing Out One of Spotify’s most listened to playlists on a rainy day, this collection of songs has over 62,000 likes and features 306 songs. It's a 19-hour collection of acoustic, alternative, indie, classic rock, and more. Wherever your musical preference lies, there are plenty of stellar tracks to get you through the wet and dreary day. Stormy weather is all about enjoying good music and warm beverages, so if you need a playlist to help set the vibe, this is the one for you. But beyond that, this is also a great playlist if you’re trying to study, take a nap, read, or enjoy some much-needed rest and relaxation. Turn Up the Volume Don’t let the rain get you down—instead, turn up the volume and explore a new world of musical enlightenment. And remember, you’ll need to download the Spotify app or use the Spotify web player to listen to this collection of playlists. Otherwise, you’ll be stuck looking out the window listening to the rain. And if you want to expand your musical horizons, we have an entire line of audio equipment and accessories to broaden your listening experience. If you have questions or would like more information, shop our online catalog, give us a call, or visit our store today. Uplifting happy type of music that makes you feel good is great if you have the rainy day blahs. Or if your into the rain and savoring it , i would say your favorite music for relaxation or classical . Classical music would be nice during the rain. Very calming and serene depending on your choice of but whatever you choose enjoy ! Upvote · Douglas Currens Author has 3.5K answers and 11.1M answer views · 10y Originally Answered: What are some good songs about rain? · Riders on the Storm - The Doors as played by every "classic rock" station on rainy days... Red Rain - Peter Gabriel Let it Rain - written by Eric Clapton with Delaney and Bonnie Bramlett (1970) Upvote · 9912 Wanja Gitau Lives in Nairobi, Kenya · Author has 171 answers and 159.9K answer views · 7y In this season Christmas carols by Bing Crosby, I love his music, also Nat King Cole Upvote · 92 Ronnie Penman Studied at The Open University · Author has 423 answers and 145.5K answer views · 1y Originally Answered: What are your favourite rain-themed songs? · Got to be the Cowsills, ‘The Rain, The Park and Other Things’ often called the flower girl. Underated band from the ’60s - they were the family band who inspired the Partridge family - seems they were originally chosen but the studio wanted to put Shirley Jones as the mother, Cowsills refused as their own mother was singing harmonies in the band. So we got the Partridge family thrust upon us, can't sing, (except David Cassidy) can't play and bad story lines. Still going to this day, sadly a few of the band have died but worth a listen. Another is the ‘The Rhythm of The Falling Rain ‘ by the Cas Continue Reading Got to be the Cowsills, ‘The Rain, The Park and Other Things’ often called the flower girl. Underated band from the ’60s - they were the family band who inspired the Partridge family - seems they were originally chosen but the studio wanted to put Shirley Jones as the mother, Cowsills refused as their own mother was singing harmonies in the band. So we got the Partridge family thrust upon us, can't sing, (except David Cassidy) can't play and bad story lines. Still going to this day, sadly a few of the band have died but worth a listen. Another is the ‘The Rhythm of The Falling Rain ‘ by the Cascades, again from the '60s, it was catchy, simple melody, and easy lyrics but again the harmonies were tight, the words were even pronounced fully, no tapering off. Great time, for me was the 60’s. Upvote · 91 Thomas Chow Lives in Hong Kong (2000–present) · Author has 82 answers and 49.3K answer views · 7y Raindrops are Falling on my Head (enough said..?)
